intro: Quercus lusitanica var. syriaca, commonly known as the Syriac oak, is a variant of the Portuguese oak, native to the mountainous regions of the eastern Mediterranean. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown and thick, fissured bark. The leaves are lobed, with a serrated margin, and turn a striking yellow or red in the autumn. Its acorns are small, enclosed in a cupule, and serve as a food source for various wildlife. This species is adapted to temperate climates and is often found in rocky or hilly terrain.
